content: It has to do with mad cow disease and I've heard about it because I was in Germany in '80 and cannot donate. Check out the following site I cut/pasted from the Google search engine: Blood Eligibility Guidelines This requirement is related to concerns about variant CJD, or 'mad cow' disease. Learn more about variant CJD and blood donation. You may not donate if you ... www.redcross.org/en/eligibility - 64k And to the OP, did you ask the folks at UBS as to why being in Germany from '80-'96 made you ineligible to donate blood? title: Unable to donate blood

content: I'm unable to donate blood because A) I had a complete blood transfusion shortly after birth, in 1981, before they started screening for HIV. This despite the fact I've tested HIV negative five or six times now. B) Lived in Germany from 1984 to 1986. C) Served in Iraq for 27 months, not sure what their cut-off is for time spent there but I've definitely exceeded it. Anyway, I'm a blood donor reject, and likely will stay that way. Kind of sucks, but I have organ donor clearly marked on my ID card, and my family is well aware of my feelings on that, so that's something.
reply: I'm unable to donate blood because A) I had a complete blood transfusion shortly after birth, in 1981, before they started screening for HIV. This despite the fact I've tested HIV negative five or six times now. B) Lived in Germany from 1984 to 1986. C) Served in Iraq for 27 months, not sure what their cut-off is for time spent there but I've definitely exceeded it. Anyway, I'm a blood donor reject, and likely will stay that way. Kind of sucks, but I have organ donor clearly marked on my ID card, and my family is well aware of my feelings on that, so that's something.

content: quote: Originally posted by 101MPRAT: There was a similar restriction for anyone who had taken malaria pills if I remember correctly. Yep, there were a bunch of us went into places "points south" for drug interdiction missions that were told not to donate blood, because of the medications we took and the bugs we may have been exposed to... That always makes ya feel just dandy, after the fact - - Wandering and Wondering

title: Unable to donate blood

content: quote: There was a similar restriction for anyone who had taken malaria pills if I remember correctly. According to the AABB (guidlines which regulte Blood Donor/ blood product handling), the restriction for malaria is 5 years. However, the ARC has their own guidlines: If we tell you can't give, it's forever. Of course this is an unwritten rule, but I know I've been "perm. banned" from donating, due to the whole malaria-thing. By the way, I have never been diagnosed with malaria, nor, have I ever had any problems with any of the miriad testing done on donor blood. Too bad the ARC has that many O-Neg peopple on the call roster, that they can ban people for no real reason!!
quote: There was a similar restriction for anyone who had taken malaria pills if I remember correctly.
reply: According to the AABB (guidlines which regulte Blood Donor/ blood product handling), the restriction for malaria is 5 years. However, the ARC has their own guidlines: If we tell you can't give, it's forever. Of course this is an unwritten rule, but I know I've been "perm. banned" from donating, due to the whole malaria-thing. By the way, I have never been diagnosed with malaria, nor, have I ever had any problems with any of the miriad testing done on donor blood. Too bad the ARC has that many O-Neg peopple on the call roster, that they can ban people for no real reason!!

However, the ARC has their own guidlines: If we tell you can't give, it's forever. Of course this is an unwritten rule, but I know I've been "perm. banned" from donating, due to the whole malaria-thing. By the way, I have never been diagnosed with malaria, nor, have I ever had any problems with any of the miriad testing done on donor blood. Too bad the ARC has that many O-Neg peopple on the call roster, that they can ban people for no real reason!!
quote: There was a similar restriction for anyone who had taken malaria pills if I remember correctly.
reply: According to the AABB (guidlines which regulte Blood Donor/ blood product handling), the restriction for malaria is 5 years. content: quote: Originally posted by 19603989: I was told by the United Blood Service that the FDA will not aprove my blood for donation until the year2246 because I lived in Germany between 1980-1996. I would worry about that too much, as in all likelyhood you will not live for another 237 years.
